components.description:
The glittering flashes of sparkles. One of the world's most popular emojis, it is generally depicted as a cluster of three, yellow four-point stars, with one large sparkle and two small ones to its left or right.

Commonly used to indicate various positive sentiments, including love, happiness, beauty, gratitude, and excitement, as well as newness or cleanliness.

May also be used as a form of ‚ú®emphasis‚ú® or to convey sarcastic or mocking tones.

As of late 2023, an icon similar to the sparkles emoji is also often used within tech platforms to represent a feature that utilizes artificial intelligence.

Both Microsoft and Twitter’s sparkles were previously multicolored, while Samsung’s sparkles were previously depicted on a night sky, suggesting firework sparklers. 

Twitter's mobile app uses ‚ú® Sparkles as a button users can tap to toggle between latest and top tweets on their timeline.

Similar emojis with less implied meaning include ‚≠ê Star, üåü Glowing Star, and üí´ Dizzy.

title: Sparkles

version.description:
Released in October 2010, Unicode 6.0 was the first version of the Unicode Standard to support emoji.

Some characters in prior versions of Unicode were retroactively updated to provide an emoji presentation. This release was the first to introduce new characters for the sole purpose of compatability with emojis being used in Japan.

emoji_net_data.definition: Decorative sparkling stars, the kind that may be¬†indicate an item¬†as being ‚Äòsparkling clean‚Äô (very clean) or¬†shiny. Sparkles was approved as http://emojipedia.org/sparkles/
emoji_net_data.name: sparkles

bn:00103623a: As if shining with a brilliant light; radiant.

bn:00112200a: Shining intermittently with a sparkling light

bn:00098857a: Emitting or reflecting light readily or in large amounts

bn:00092637v: Be bright by reflecting or casting light
To bend back (light, etc.) from a surface.

bn:00073964n: Sphere of plasma held together by gravity, undergoing fusion
A luminous celestial body that is made from gases (particularly hydrogen and helium) and forms the shape of a sphere.
This article is for quotes about stars, or which make prominent mention of stars.
(astronomy) a celestial body of hot gases that radiates energy derived from thermonuclear reactions in the interior
A star is a massive, luminous sphere of plasma held together by its own gravity.
A luminous celestial body, made up of plasma (particularly hydrogen and helium) and having a spherical shape. Depending on context the sun may or may not be included.

bn:00029903n: The quality of being bright and sending out rays of light.
Power per unit solid angle per unit projected source area (W ¬∑ sr ? 1 ¬∑ m ? 2)
The flux of radiation emitted per unit solid angle in a given direction by a unit area of a source.
The flux of radiation emitted per unit solid angle in a given direction by a unit area of a source
A radiometric measure that describes the amount of light that passes through or is emitted from a particular area, and falls within a given solid angle in a specified direction.
Radiance and spectral radiance are measures of the quantity of radiation that passes through or is emitted from a surface and falls within a given solid angle in a specified direction.
The quality of being bright and sending out rays of light
Effulgence is a state of being bright and radiant, splendor, brilliance, and its two related terms are effulgent and refulgence.
